entry.title: Combined summary - Taproot activation proposal "Speedy Trial"
entry.summary: Bitcoin developers have proposed several activation mechanisms for the Taproot soft fork on the Bitcoin network. One such proposal is called Speedy Trial, which aims to allow a taproot activation attempt to either quickly succeed or quickly fail without compromising safety in either case. The activation method involves miners signaling their readiness for the upgrade during a three-month period, after which it will lock in if at least 90% of blocks mined include the signal. False signaling by miners remains a potential issue, but this is common to all activation methods.The proposal can be implemented using either Bitcoin Core's existing BIP9 code or its proposed BIP8 patchset. BIP8 uses height-based parameters for miners to lock in Taproot within six retarget periods and a certain number of blocks. However, some concerns were raised during discussions about the proposed three-month window, stating that it may not be short enough to prevent a network split due to divergent consensus rules. Others argued that designing activation mechanisms to prevent others from exercising self-determination over which consensus rules their nodes enforce goes against the principles of decentralization.There are concerns about false signaling and unprepared miners losing money with this approach. To mitigate these problems, new rules added in a soft fork need to be enforced by a large part of the economy. Developers have taken steps in the past to ensure widespread adoption of new consensus rules by programming in a delay between when software is expected to be released and when the software starts tracking which blocks signal for activation. Speedy Trial replaces most of that upfront delay with a backend delay.Overall, the proposed Speedy Trial activation method could generate fast progress towards taproot activation on the Bitcoin network. The implementation details and next steps of the proposal are still being discussed, and several links and references related to the activation of Taproot were shared on the bitcoin-dev mailing list. There have also been other proposals for activating Taproot, including a modification to the activation approach called Speedy Trial, which could either quickly succeed or quickly fail without compromising safety. Another proposal involves a three-month timeline for activating Taproot. While some people are unsure about this timeline, others believe it provides miners with a reasonable amount of time to activate Taproot without delaying any existing proposals with roughly one-year timelines.The proposed activation plan assumes a mid-April release of Bitcoin Core 0.21.1 containing these parameters. The timeline includes an extended lock-in period of 14112 blocks, which is seven retarget periods. False signaling is possible with any other proposal, but the same problems can occur if miners fail to upgrade for any mandatory activation. The discussion highlighted the importance of careful consideration and planning for the activation of Taproot, given its potential impact on the Bitcoin network.There have also been concerns about the potential risks of a User Activated Soft Fork (UASF) during a "Speedy Trial" deployment, as well as the possibility of a significant delay before activation occurs if the activation fails. Additionally, there is concern that if the activation fails, there may be a significant delay before activation occurs.Overall, the activation of Taproot has been a topic of discussion among Bitcoin developers since at least 2020, with previous proposals and discussions dating back to 2015 and 2016. The proposed activation plans aim to ensure widespread adoption of new consensus rules while maintaining safety. It is important to carefully consider potential risks and plan for activation to ensure the robustness and security of the Bitcoin network.
